text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen 
today we're going to make a recipe that

really I should have made a long time ago because 
it's so popular but for whatever reason I never

got around to it we are making yellow curry 
now yellow curry in Thai is called gaeng garee

now gaeng means curry but garee does not mean 
yellow okay this might get a little confusing

there is something called Kang Lou young which is 
literally yellow curry but that's another curry

that you probably haven't had so it could get a 
little confusing garee on the other hand means

curry so if you're like yes it's curry curry 
but Guddi in Thai comes from the word curry

in a sense of an Indian curry because that's 
where the influence of this curry comes from

so you're gonna see in our curry paste there's 
going to be a lot of Indian spices that don't

show up often other Thai dishes so we're going 
to do this in two parts first we're going to

make the curry paste and then we're going to go 
and make the curry so first the ingredients for

the curry paste dry spices coriander seeds 
cumin seed white peppercorns curry powder

so and dry to me next though right going going 
gone ginger to work and finally some shallots

garlic lemongrass shrimp paste so the Chili's 
I'm using dry large Chili's today which is what

we typically use for curry paste they're less 
spicy so what I'm going to do is going to be a

little different from what I have you've seen my 
red curry paste or Panang curry paste episodes

this is going to be a different technique because 
I've discovered that it's faster this way so I'm

going to cut them into chunks first now in those 
episodes I soaked them in water and rehydrate them

before I start pounding them and as you see I've 
discovered something more efficient the seats I

don't really care for but I'm not going to ask 
you cut them to see it's most of them are going

to fall out anyway and then what I'm going to do 
is I'm going to grind it in my coffee grinder here

now coffee grinder is great for doing dry things 
like chili so this one I actually used only for

Chili's you know I don't use for my coffee because 
I'm like healthy would be very very spicy coffee

grinders are great for pulverizing dry ingredients 
now if I try to do the whole curry paste in here

it won't grind it as finely as a mortar and pestle 
because they don't handle wet stuff very well so

that's why but chilies are the hardest thing to 
grind in a mortar and pestle because the skin

is so stubborn so if I get them done here first 
it'll speed things up so much more so here we go

you grind Chili's in the coffee grinder or any 
electric device make sure you let the dust settle

for a few seconds before you open it I like to 
sort of tap it yeah I remember being traumatized

by this we made chili flakes once as a kid and 
whoever was making it open the thing without

without letting it settle and I happen to be in 
the vicinity and it was not pleasant let me tell

you okay so this is pretty good I still have 
a couple of big chunks but it's not a big deal

most of it is gone and this is going to speed 
up your curry paste making by a lot so moving

on we're going to now get our mortar and pestle 
involved so first thing whenever you are making

curry paste always start with grinding your 
dry spices and do them separately so in goes

my toasted coriander seeds notice I said toasted 
and cumin seeds are white peppercorns yep that's

all we need to grind anyway gotta start kind of 
gently so they don't jump at you but once the

oh like that one did mmm the smell cumin and 
coriander okay and we're just going to remove

it because right now if I start grinding all the 
rough all that all the lemongrass and whatnot it's

gonna just be act like a cushion a little bit 
so I like to take it out first and now to this

I'm also going to just mix in our other dry things 
which is curry powder now curry powder this is the

same mix that I used in my pineapple fried rice 
and I bought the curry powder I smelled it and

I thought do I really like the smell of this and I 
thought no so I doctored it and I added a bunch of

other spices so point being there is no one type 
of curry powder that you must use if you like the

smell of the one that you have go ahead use it if 
not you can find other mixes you can go to Indian

stores and see what they have usually they have a 
lot of selection but whatever you like it's going

to be good in the curry because if you even if 
you buy a Thai brand you don't like the smell

you're not going to like it in the curry so that's 
what I did so got that that's our dry spices we're

going to set that aside and then we're going to 
go back and start pounding our sturdy herbs now

by 30 herbs I'm talking about the lemongrass 
galangal and ginger now that I've chopped them

up because if you chop them up then it takes 
you less time in the mortar I'm also going to

add my turmeric but one inch knob of turmeric 
I'm adding it whole now I'm not I didn't peel

it because I washed it really well these things 
grow underground so you want to wash it really

well but I don't really think peeling makes much 
of a difference the skin is so thin and I also

didn't want to chop it ahead of time because 
I don't want to stain my cutting board forever

yellow like I've done before so I'm going to put 
it in whole and I'm also going to add to this my

salt normally I'd use coarse coarser grained salt 
but I forgot it so so a note about turmeric that's

the thing that makes this curry yellow but if 
you add too much tumeric it does not taste good

if you ever taste turmeric by itself it's not a 
pleasant flavor but it adds a nice color and and

subtle flavors to other things now if you follow 
me on Facebook you know I tried making a turmeric

shake ones and that didn't go very well so once 
things start to mush but it's not fine yet it's

going to start getting a little bit wet especially 
if you've got frozen previously frozen things in

there this is where I like to add my dry stuff 
back in because the dry stuff helps absorb the

liquid and prevent it from splashing in your face 
like it usually does to me so this really helps

oh okay we're almost done I just prefer pounding 
it on the floor because it's just more comfortable

sitting down so what you look for as far as 
consistency is basically get it as fine as

you can you know this is pretty good most of the 
little bits are just bits of garlic and shallots

doesn't not a big deal because when you make 
it into a curry those things will disintegrate

anyway so but most of our chunky fiber stuff is 
gone the last thing that needs to go in is our

shrimp paste standard ingredient for most Thai 
curries if you're trying to make this vegetarian

it is okay to leave it out your curry will still 
be delicious just be aware that you might need

more salt more fish sauce well is shrinking that 
more slices or salt in the final curry than what

I'm using okay and that you're just going to 
mix it all up and it's pretty much done that

is our curry paste so this is enough for one 
recipe one big curry that's going to serve

about four people and that is it that is our 
yellow curry paste now next we're going to turn

this actually into a delicious yellow chicken 
curry with potatoes and onions so stay tuned

for our next episode and now in the meantime if 
you're interested in this recipe with all the

ingredients and everything visit my website hot 
a kitchen calm it will be under the tutorials

page on which you will also find recipes for 
red curry paste and Panang curry paste so you

can explore to your heart's content and if you 
enjoy the show please click to subscribe so

I can keep doing what I'm doing and I will see 
you next time for your next delicious Thai meal
